titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Dean Rusk Papers FA056

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-18 01:59:33 -0400.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is organized in four series:

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: David Dean Rusk was born on February 9, 1909, in Cherokee County, Georgia, the fourth of five children of Robert Hugh Rusk and Francis Clotfelter Rusk. In 1931 he graduated from Davidson College. In 1934, as a Rhodes Scholar at St. John's College at Oxford University, Mr. Rusk earned a master's degree in politics, economics, and philosophy.

Mr. Rusk then worked at Mills College in Oakland, California, from 1934 to 1940, teaching government and international relations and serving as dean of faculty while also studying law at the University of California at Berkeley. During the Second World War Mr. Rusk, an Army Reserve officer, served on active duty from 1940 until 1946, rising to the rank of colonel.

Mr. Rusk joined the State Department in 1946 as assistant chief of the division of international security affairs and was later appointed Special Assistant to the Secretary of War. From 1947 to 1949, he was head of the State Department's United Nations desk. From 1949 to 1951, in succession, Mr. Rusk became an Assistant Secretary of State, a Deputy Under Secretary of State, and Assistant Secretary for Far Eastern Affairs.

In March 1952 Mr. Rusk left the State Department to succeed Chester I. Barnard as president of The Rockefeller Foundation. During his eight years with the Foundation, Mr. Rusk oversaw the distribution of about $250,000,000 for various projects, including aid to underdeveloped nations in Asia, Africa, and Latin America. Mr. Rusk also gave numerous speeches to various organizations and institutions and published several articles on U. S. foreign policy, diplomacy, and the role of philanthropy in American society.

On December 12, 1960, President-elect John F. Kennedy designated Mr. Rusk to be Secretary of State. On January 21, 1961, Mr. Rusk was sworn in to head the State Department. He served in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations until 1969. In 1970 Mr. Rusk returned to Georgia and taught international law at the University of Georgia at Athens until his retirement in 1984.
Mr. Rusk married Virginia Foisie in 1937. They had three children, David, Richard, and Peggy Smith.
Mr. Rusk died December 20, 1994, at his home in Athens, Georgia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Dean Rusk Papers document the non-official professional activities of Dean Rusk (1909-1994), carried out during his tenure as president of the Rockefeller Foundation from 1952 to 1961. There are no personal papers in this small collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: This small collection complements the Rusk material that is maintained as part of the archives of The Rockefeller Foundation. The Foundation archives contain a relatively brief officer's diary kept by Rusk, and correspondence by and to him. The most substantive correspondence appears in numerous grant administration (Record Group 1) and program and policy (Record Group 3) files. This documentation shows the Foundation's president in many respects functioning as a first among equals, often actively exchanging views with division officers and then making a final decision. Mr. Rusk's Secretary of State records are housed in the National Archives in Washington, D.C.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research ith select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

controlaccess.subject: Public welfare
Philanthropy
Taxation -- Law and legislation -- United States
International relations -- United States -- 1950-1960.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically and by correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 1 contains five folders of correspondence (1950-1969) between Rusk and various academic, political, and philanthropic leaders, including Henry Kissinger, Dean Acheson, Eleanor Roosevelt, Adlai Stevenson, Senator Ralph E. Flanders, and Raymond Fosdick. The correspondence covers such topics as meetings to discuss the defense of Europe, the implications of the Korean War, operation of the United Nations, foreign affairs, and Rusk's opinions on his colleagues' writings on foreign policy.

Also present in Series 1 is correspondence (1958-1960) relating to the U.S. Senate Subcommittee on Policy, which was chaired by Senator Henry Jackson, to study the effectiveness of existing national security policy in regard to communism. Rusk's correspondence with Senator Jackson reveals Rusk's thoughts and advice on the study.

did.unittitle: United States Government - National Academy of Sciences - Academy of Public Affairs
United States Government - Senate Subcommittee on Policy
United States Government - Senate Subcommittee on Policy - Statements by Committee and by Senator Henry Jackson

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically by date of publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of the articles in this series discuss U.S. foreign policy and diplomacy during the 1950's at the height of the Cold War.

did.unittitle: Statement Before Investigative Committee - 83rd Congress - Rockefeller Foundation (RF) and General Education Board (GEB)

Replies to Dean Rusk Article, "The President"

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically by the date of the speech. The series also includes an index of speeches given between 1951 and 1960; the index is located at the beginning of the series in folder 32.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 3, Speeches, which represents nearly three-quarters of the collection, contains copies of the speeches Rusk gave to various organizations and institutions from 1951 to 1961, together with notes and correspondence.

Among the central themes of Rusk's speeches are foreign policy and the promotion of American democracy, particularly with regard to the Soviet Union, Korea, Japan, and the operation of the United Nations. Folder 36 contains a copy of the unofficial text of the Security Treaty between the U.S. and Japan (1952). In folder 88 there is correspondence from Harry S. Truman (1960), in which Truman responds to Rusk's recently published article "The President" in "Foreign Affairs" (1960).

Other speeches concern the role of philanthropy, the importance of public and social welfare, and the contributions of The Rockefeller Foundation. Two folders in particular address this theme in a political context. Folders 53 and 54 contain material on the Reece Committee (1954) that was formed to investigate tax-exempt foundations, including The Rockefeller Foundation and the General Education Board, and to decide if legislation should be passed that would affect foundations. Folder 53 contains the combined statement of The Rockefeller Foundation and the General Education Board to the Reece Committee (1954). Present in folder 54 is the text of Rusk's remarks (1954) to the staff of The Rockefeller Foundation concerning the Reece Committee and Rusk's reactions to allegations that philanthropy supported something of a left-wing influence in American society.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Photographs, slides, and other images are open for scholarly research.

RAC is unable to provide access to obsolete media and original digital media. In addition separated media may not yet have undergone stabilization procedures. When feasible, a digital surrogate may be created via special order. All applicable charges will apply.
Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be closed to researchers.
